awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Cultivating a Smart Equity-Driven Policymaking Infrastructure to Improve Youth Learning Opportunities
awd_abstract_narration:
Amid growing commitment to address inequities of access to quality learning, this Smart and Connected Communities Planning Grant supports the creation of a collaborative working group consisting of Chicago city agencies, community-based out-of-school time (OST) program providers, schools, funding organizations, families, and youth in Chicago to create a smart, equitable out-of-school learning infrastructure that more effectively allocates learning resources, such as spaces, mentors, technology, and funding, in order to eradicate out-of-school learning deserts in Chicago. This project responds to the critical need to build and strengthen connections among stakeholders, including city agencies, informal educators, out-of-school program leaders, school district leaders, parents, and youth, with an evidence-based understanding of OST offerings. Information about the abundance and diversity of programs and provider organizations, location of programs, capacity of programs, youth interest, and youth population can be used to effectively improve the health of Chicago’s OST learning ecosystem. This project will contribute an actionable framework consisting of policies, practices, funding models, and collaboration structures that support a smart, data-driven method to create equitable out-of-school learning opportunities.

Working in an existing OST learning ecosystem, this project takes a community-driven approach to evaluating the current OST learning landscape by bringing together key stakeholders and facilitating the conversation using interactive smart tools such as data visualizations and GIS maps, that layer community-based OST program, city, and demographic data. This information can help stakeholders discuss and expand and diversify OST learning opportunities and participation among youth in resource-constrained communities. The outcome will be a socio-technical framework, co-created with key learning stakeholders in Chicago, that will include a suite of smart, data-driven technologies that enable a robust, out-of-school learning ecosystem customized to the needs of neighborhood youth. This actionable framework will consist of policies, practices, and structures at both the city and community levels derived from defining a socio-technical infrastructure and shared language, identifying policies and practices that inhibit or support collaboration among learning stakeholders, and co-creating practices for community-based collaboration to transform and activate a new OST ecosystem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
High-quality out-of-school time (OST) learning opportunities such as afterschool programming, summer programming, sports, and tutoring make up an important part of the overall learning ecosystem for youth. Youth from lower-income communities in particular benefit from participating  in such OST programming in the STEM areas; however, such opportunities are not always available or accessible, nor are they equitably distributed across areas. This research involved bringing together representatives from community organizations and city agencies to look at data about how such programs are distributed across the greater Chicago area. Focusing on one historically disadvantaged area in Chicago (the Austin community) as a case study, researchers partnered with a STEM OST organization that was embedded in the community to work with local OST providers, family services, city departments, young people, and others to identify their  particular needs, barriers, and goals related to OST programming. Through the process of hosting monthly community conversations, the researchers and community co-developed interactive mapping tools designed to increase community capacity for advocacy in support of more equitable policymaking and sustain the community's efforts after the research ended. 

At the start of the project, researchers collaborated with community members to create interactive community maps to visualize key public data related to unemployment, income, race, educational level, youth density, violent crime, and other factors alongside citywide data related to OST program locations, types, content areas, target ages, etc. Through a series of community conversations, these maps were updated to reflect other factors of relevance, such as walkability. Importantly, community members reflected on the initial data and visualizations provided and shared experiences that supported, contradicted, or provided nuance to them. Using and updating these maps with additional relevant data allowed representatives of city agencies, OST providers, community organizations, funders, parents, and youth to determine specific, relevant questions such as where summer coding programs for middle schoolers were located, and how available and accessible (e.g., safe, welcoming, walkable) such programs were for those living in a lower income community. 

As community members analyzed the data based on their own interests and needs, they identified questions for which new data needed to be collected. Focusing on available resources already held in the community--an asset-based approach--neighborhood youth received training in how to collect community data and then conducted surveys of the existing community resources such as makerspaces and  kitchen spaces that could be purposed for OST activities. Researchers and community participants also gathered data from their local public schools and community organizations about additional OST programming offerings and intentions. These additional data were then added to the community maps and supported further inquiries from the community.

High-level activities and outcomes of this work included:

  • Nineteen community workshops engaging more than 200 representatives from community-based providers, city agencies (parks, libraries, office of disabilities, public schools, public health, and family support service), and families with data and maps that illuminated key facts about resource distribution and guided further data collection and analysis. (More than half of these attendees participated in more than one meeting.)

  • Twelve teens and 5 college-age facilitators from the community engaged in data collection and investigation of their own questions regarding OST.

  • Three resident-initiated working groups developed to address community-identified goals to 1) create a network of connected hubs for service providers; 2) identify and publicize mental health resources and advocate for more resources; and 3) establish and integrate youth leadership development into community initiatives.

Participation in this community-led activity increased empowerment. For example,

  • Residents assumed active roles on existing citywide initiatives that focus on OST activities for youth (e.g., activities at parks and libraries, online youth learning activities as a result of COVID-19), ensuring that their local neighborhoods needs would be addressed.

  • Community participants planned and coordinated local summer programming and shared it with the mayor's office for city-wide exposure.

  • A public school system leader began to collect and share data about opportunities for OST learning and connected OST providers with the school.

  • Community organizations within the Austin neighborhood developed networks to facilitate informal education during the pandemic, leveraging paid staff, learning supplies, and outreach and coordination functions from different groups to provide access to online tutoring.

  • Based on the blueprint of this project, other communities have received funding to engage in mapping their community resources and making them more accessible to residents. 

Working with data, visualizations, and maps enabled stakeholders--residents of Chicago's Austin neighborhood--to engage in community conversations to identify opportunities and  barriers to equitable OST learning spaces. By accessing, analyzing, visualizing, and questioning data, residents developed new skills in making data-driven cases for the programs and services that would best serve local families. Residents leveraged these skills to support informal learning during the pandemic and to advocate for additional community resources. This project focused on actualizing a vision of equity.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/27/2023
Modified by: Sheena Erete
